Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this award is to formulate a methodology and system for the micro-manipulation of a waterjet serving as a laser beam waveguide leading to the development of a new multi-functional hybrid waterjet-guided laser micro-manufacturing process and machine capable of laser ablation, micro-cutting, surface micro-texturing and modification and micro-incremental forming. The salient characteristic of the envisioned process rests in the possibility of simultaneously using thermal and mechanical actions with different attributes in controlled proportions. The approach will be the use of a controlled electrostatic field generated by a multi-pole actuator to bend the waterjet waveguide and, thereby, control the spatial orientation, the position of impingement, direction of lasing action and the force the waterjet exerts on the workpiece. The principal tasks will be: (1) waterjet waveguide characterization; (2) waterjet bending and control through an electrostatic actuator; (3) waterjet-guided micro-incremental forming process development; and (4) construction of an experimental prototype machine to serve as a vehicle for process model and technology verification.

If successful, this research will lead to a new ability to manufacture three-dimensional micro-features on metallic and non-metallic parts without relocating the part, which will lead to enhanced precision. The physical interaction of the waterjet and laser beam will open process windows for achieving deformation, cutting, and surface treatment of the workpiece material in a single hybrid integrated manufacturing machine. Process productivity will be considerably enhanced because of the anticipated high process bandwidth. The project will provide training to a diverse group of graduate and undergraduate students and practitioners through research opportunities, course projects and short courses.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
The use of waterjet-guided laser systems has not been yet sufficiently explored beyond the domain of unidirectional, planar cutting and patterning operations, and especially not in the processing of non-planar surfaces and 3D structures. In actuality, the potentials of this technology are exploited only to a very limited extent. The possibility of using innovative enhancements of the basic process and the possibility of broadening its domain of applications by combining it with other processing methods motivated this work. The specific research objective of this project was the formulation of a methodology and system for the micro-manipulation of a waterjet, serving as a laser beam waveguide, by the use of electrostatic fields to widen the range of process capabilities of this technology in terms of versatility, accuracy and productivity.

 The underlying idea was the realization of an augmented process that utilizes an innovative mechanism to manipulate the trajectory of the waterjet waveguide that rests on the principle of deflection of the waterjet under the influence controlled electrostatic fields. The salient characteristic of the envisioned process rests in the possibility of simultaneously using thermal and mechanical actions with different attributes in controlled proportions. In the approach developed, controlled electrostatic fields are generated by electrostatic actuators consisting of multiple electrodes to bend the waterjet waveguide and, thereby, control its spatial orientation, position of impingement, direction of the lasing action and the force that it exerts on the workpiece. The principal issues addressed, through a combination of analytical and pragmatic developments, ranged from jet stability, jet geometrical deviations, waveguide properties and electrostatic force generation ability through the modeling and control of the deflection and position of jet impingement on the workpiece to the process mechanics of the micro-incremental forming operation and the experimental verification of the developed theoretical models and of the pragmatic technological solutions. For the ultimate assessment of the feasibility of the proposed principles a waterjet-guided laser micro-manufacturing testbed/machine was designed, built and tested.

 The results accomplished through this research lay the  foundation for the development of a family of novel multi-functional hybrid waterjet-guided laser micro-manufacturing process and machines capable of laser ablation, micro-cutting, surface micro-texturing and modification and micro-incremental forming to mention a few. Such processes have the potential to offer as of yet unattained abilities for manufacturing three-dimensional micro-features and locally affecting material properties of metallic and non-metallic parts. Many of these actions can be achieved without relocating the part leading to enhanced precision. Considerable enhancements of process productivity are anticipated due to the high process bandwidths. 

 


Last Modified: 10/16/2017
Modified by: Kornel F Ehmann

The salient characteristic of the envisioned process rests in the possibility of simultaneously using thermal and mechanical actions with different attributes in controlled proportions. Such processes have the potential to offer as of yet unattained abilities for manufacturing three-dimensional micro-features and locally affecting material properties of metallic and non-metallic parts.
